title: Catalyst Interactive News Journal
description: Community members have no way to be rewarded for contributing stories of their Catalyst journeys, and voting on the contributions of others

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal definitely is about Distributed Decision Making, but not in direct link with the Catalyst process. It's aim is to create the 'first distributed news journal on Earth'. Very interesting application, but according to my interpretation not fully fitting into this Challenge Setting. This challenge has defined the following goal: 'How can we help the Catalyst community to get better at distributed decision making within the next two Catalyst rounds?'

For future proposals, I suggest to comply more directly with a Challenge Setting's goals. A pitty: This is a very appealing proposal, but due to the 'misplacement' I cannot unconditionally support it.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team behind this proposal is definitely very experienced and engaged within the Catalyst activities. They are all highly engaged community members with a collective background in writing, project management, content creation & community outreach. From this perspective, I consider it very feasible that the outlined goals of the proposal can be achieved (even if I see these goals not fully aligned with the Challenge Setting's goals, see my comments under Impact). 

One other concern I have here is that the suggested news-story-voting has (initially) nothing directly to do with the Core-Catalyst Decision Making. I suggest to keep this quite separate for avoiding confusion.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposing team properly outlines the activity roadmap and the way, progress and success can be audited. 

Due to their strong entanglement and engagement within the Catalyst Community, this coukd become integral part of various meeting formats (e.g. Townhalls).

f6_assessments.q0: Yes, it is a very interesting approach for people to get active and it will serve several important purposes that can develop the community and it´s diverse skillsets as well as decisionmaking. Challengewise, it fits to Experiments in social, collaboration, or meeting structures in that it iterates publication processes - which are very similar to our important funding related roles "writing proposals and assessing proposals and also voting" - but it brings it on a more personal level (or any other level that I´m not thinking of right now). In it´s openness it might add perspectives and facilitate sharing. By voting for stories and learning how the stories go through the steps of the publication process the proposers are utilizing a meta-process similar to the funding cycle in Catalyst which is pretty cool in itself and it might also be be a good way to share different perspectives, have "themed special issues" and grow as a community. Great idea.
f6_assessments.q1: Yes, I know that Ben has a writing background, Felix has experience with project management and general networking as well as Raz. All members are very active and have already contributed greatly to the community in several areas but also in toolmaking/decisionmaking so the proposed idea is definitely within their range of experience. It is highly likely that this way of contribution from the community will be set up by the team and running smoothly, the idea to introduce it through ATH as well as through the communication channels and swarm is feasable and will help get people curious. The financial budget is very well broken down, but with 25.000 the project requests a third of the funding so it is quite high.
f6_assessments.q2: The roadmap and milestones are feasable and the proposed release date is communicated. Communication as well as documentation is given through bi-weekly ATH breakout rooms and open documentation that can be audited. Rewards are calculated, voting process is described thoroughly, outreach is coverd through discord and other communication channels as well as swarm and ATH. Bounty as well as voting and contributing will lead to a more active participation and as mentioned - the process mirrors the funding round process (kind of) so it will be a great way to experience the "big" Catalyst funding circles through "smaller" timeframes of publication rounds. Very interesting.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal encourages participation, but on a silo'd platform for the foreseeable future. It is difficult for me to see how this proposal would directly and strongly influence decision making that goes beyond the scope of content reporting/creation.
f6_assessments.q1: The detailed plan outlines the skill and the implementation plan in a sufficient manner; it appears the proposal team is capable and likely to execute the plan successfully. The budget is understandable and reasonable.
f6_assessments.q2: The information provided is sufficient to audit - especially once the data lives on-chain.

f6_assessments.q0: Proposal's challenge was that community members have no way to be rewarded for contributing stories of their Catalyst journeys, and voting on the contributions of others by creating a distributed news journal that incentivizes an interactive community for submitting content, and voting on the stories they read.
f6_assessments.q1: The team that will implement this are highly engaged community members with a collective background in writing, project management, content creation & community outreach. Has a descent experience on implementing such project.
f6_assessments.q2: As the news journal will be designed on a website, the achievements and evolution can be constantly tracked and documented. They will provide a bi-weekly breakout room in the Catalyst After Town Halls to allow the community to interact directly with the team.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal effectively addresses the challenge of getting more journalist involved in writing articles and creating a distributed news journal that incentivizes an interactive community for submitting content, and voting on the stories they read.
f6_assessments.q1: The 3 team members are highly qualified and the plan that is presented can be successful based on the milestones and timelines.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal can be easily audited for success, but the timeline to complete the initial goals may be a bit ambitious to achieve in January 2022 with the release of official Onchain CINJ version 1.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal creatively provides the digital and incentive structure to build a new decentralized space for journalism. The potential benefit here is in providing new information sharing and creative outlets for the Catalyst community while normalizing and legitimizing decentralized decision making. This potentially looks like a space where new diffusions of leadership roles and journalistic exchanges are forged. It makes sense to give a community of readers the ability to choose their level of participation in what they are reading, up to and including making submissions, voting on content, and direct editorial feedback. The responsibly apportioned initial incentives to contributors, stake pool synchronicity, and nft plans all point to the team having considered the scalability of the project carefully and from multiple angles. This proposal speaks to the challenge clearly with a well-defined idea of how to add value to the community.
f6_assessments.q1: Razali and Felix are involved and trusted community members, and Benjamin's journalism experience is ultra-relevant to the proposal as well. Having the talent in-house that's already committed to implementation is quite reassuring. The plan is detailed but implementation looks well-covered with the team's pre-existing familiarity with the relevant off-chain apps. The budget, ⅓ of the fund pool,  is reasonable given the size of the potential community impact. The plan looks feasibly implementable.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal includes a well-considered and realistic roadmap with specific measurable goals that all make good sense in the context of the proposed timeline. Similarly, the post-Town Hall breakout room and publicly available website design should make transparency, tracking, and community feedback all fairly organic. The attention to incentives and promotion within the community tell me this team takes this set of challenges seriously. This proposal's progress will be able to be easily measured.

f6_assessments.q0: a very original idea, I see a large potential in it. Such possibility can increase both number of people interested in cardano and crypto in general, and share of the community voted news. Motivating people to post a high quality "information" and therefore increase the shared-knowledge of the community can definitely increase the decision making process, when the community is "more" informed.
f6_assessments.q1: there is only one linked in link, more would be better to verify the competence. Nevertheless, if the stated information is true - that all co-workers are successful proposer from the previous funds, I will consider them as an appropriate team to pull it off.
f6_assessments.q2: The working webpage and the number of articles can provide information for auditing the proposal. Also, the metrics of new people would be nice to have (which I believe is something standard - some stats) and therefore it can be easily evaluated. A tricky part is how to evaluate a high quality articles + how it improves decision making. These are definitely hard to track, and right now, I do not come up with an idea how to measure it. Overall, this idea is great, and I believe that it can attract and motivate people to post articles and share the knowledge, which can result in increased decision making.

solution: Creating a distributed news journal that incentivizes an interactive community for submitting content, and voting on the stories they read.
experience: Highly engaged community members with a collective background in writing, project management, content creation & community outreach.
